Aircraft fleet renewal is an important component of our environmental sustainability strategy, which will continue to require extensive capital investment in future periods . The project cost approximately $4.2 billion and was funded through debt issuance, existing cash and a Port Authority contribution of approximately $500 million . We entered into loan agreements to fund a portion of the construction, which are recorded on our Consolidated Balance Sheets ("balance sheets") as debt .
 A substantial majority of the project costs were funded through the Regional Airports Improvement Corporation ("RAIC"), a California public benefit corporation, using a revolving credit facility . Loans made under the credit facility are being repaid with the proceeds from the City of Los Angeles' purchase of completed project assets . In 2024, we had cash outflows of approximately $4.0 billion related to repayments of our debt and finance leases, including approximately $1.1 billion of early repayments .
 Fitch and S&P Global upgraded their credit ratings of Delta to BBB-, an investment grade rating . The principal amount of our debt and finance leases was $16.2 billion at December 31, 2024 . We have now achieved investment-grade ratings across the major credit rating agencies, including Moody's .
 Board of Directors approved and we will pay a quarterly dividend of $0.15 per share on March 20, 2025 to shareholders of record as of February 27, 2025 . Total dividend payments during the year ended December 31, 2024 were $321 million . Delta Air Lines was in compliance with the covenants in our debt agreements at December 31, 2024 .
 The SkyMiles program includes two types of transactions that are considered revenue arrangements with multiple performance obligations . The aggregate deferred revenue balance associated with the program was $8.8 billion at December 31, 2024 . A hypothetical 10% change in the number of outstanding miles estimated to have a material impact on our revenue in the year in which the change occurs .
 Customers earn miles based on their spending with participating companies, such as credit card, ridesharing, retail, car rental and hotel companies . Payments are typically due to us monthly based on the volume of miles sold during the period . A hypothetical 10% increase in our estimate of the ETV of a mile would have decreased total operating revenue by less than 1% for the year ended December 31, 2024 .
 Delta Air Lines, Inc. | 2024 Form 10-K: We sell miles to American Express which are then provided to their customers under the co-brand credit card program and the Membership Rewards program . Cardholders earn miles for making purchases using co-branded cards, and certain cardholders may also receive baggage fee waivers, lounge access, priority boarding and other benefits while traveling on Delta .
 Revenue allocated to services performed in conjunction with a passenger’s flight is recognized as travel-related services in passenger revenue . The timing of mile redemptions can vary widely; however, the majority of new miles have historically been redeemed within two years of being earned . For tickets that we sell on behalf of other airlines, we reduce the air traffic liability .
 At December 31, 2024, the aggregate air traffic liability balance was $7.1 billion . Ticket breakage estimates are primarily based on historical experience, ticket contract terms and customers’ travel behavior . A hypothetical 10% change in the amount of tickets estimated to expire unused would result in an impact of less than 1% of total operating revenue for the year ended December 31, 2024 .
 The key assumptions in our impairment tests include forecasted revenues, expenses and cash flows, (2) current discount rates, (3) observable market transactions and (4) anticipated changes to the regulatory environment (e.g., changes in slot access and/or availability, additional Open Skies agreements or changes to antitrust approvals)
 Changes in certain events and circumstances could result in impairment or a change from indefinite-lived to definite-lived . Factors which could cause impairment include (1) negative trends in our market capitalization, (2) reduced profitability resulting from lower passenger mile yields or higher input costs, (3) lower passenger demand as a result of weakened U.S. and global economies or other factors .
 As of December 31, 2024, the funded status for these plans recorded on our balance sheets was $938 million . The most critical assumptions impacting our defined benefit pension plan obligations, plan assets, net periodic cost/(benefit) are the discount rate, the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets and life expectancy of plan participants .
 The investment strategy for our defined benefit pension plan assets is to earn a long-term return that meets or exceeds our annualized return target . This is achieved by investing in a globally diversified mix of public and private equity, fixed income, real assets, hedge funds and other assets and instruments . We review our rate of return on plan assets assumptions annually .
 Our funding obligations for qualified defined benefit plans are governed by ERISA and any additional applicable legislation . Under current legislation, any required funding would be amortized over a rolling 15-year period . Assumptions include, among other things, the actual and projected market performance of assets, statutory requirements and demographic data for participants .
 Delta Air Lines, Inc. adopted this standard effective January 1, 2024 . We are assessing the impact of this ASU and may be required to include certain additional disclosures .
 Non-GAAP financial measures may be considered in addition to results prepared in accordance with GAAP, but should not be considered a substitute for or superior to GAAP results .  The volatility in fuel prices impacts the comparability of year-over-year financial performance . The adjustment for aircraft fuel and related taxes allows investors to better understand and analyze our non-fuel costs . The adjusted profit sharing adjustment provides a more meaningful comparison of our airline operations to the rest of the airline industry . Foreign currency exchange rate risk because we have revenue, expense and equity investments denominated in foreign currencies .
 At December 31, 2024, our investments denominated in foreign currencies (AirFrance-KLM, China Eastern, Hanjin-KAL and LATAM) were recorded at a fair value of $1.6 billion . A 10% change in the value of those respective currencies against the U.S. dollar would have an approximately $160 million impact on our financial statements .
 In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company at December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years .  Firm conducted audits in accordance with standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB) Firm's report dated February 11, 2025 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon . Firm's responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company’s financial statements based on our audits . Firm is registered with the PCAOB and is required to be independent with respect to the Company . Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024 .
 At December 31, 2024, the fair value of the Company’s benefit plan assets measured at fair value on a recurring basis totaled $15.7 billion, of which $12.4 billion do not have a readily determinable fair value . We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion. The communication of critical audit matters does not alter in any way our opinion on the consolidated financial statements, taken as a whole .
 At December 31, 2024, the Company’s aggregate current and noncurrent loyalty program deferred revenue balance was $8.8 billion . The Company defers revenue for mileage credits earned and recognizes loyalty travel awards in passenger revenue as the miles are redeemed and services are provided . For the year ended December 31, 2024 .
 The Company recognizes mileage breakage proportionally during the period in which the remaining mileage credits are redeemed . Under the Company’s loyalty program, mileage credits do not expire . Therefore, the Company uses statistical models to estimate mileage breakages based on historical redemption patterns . The Company's audit procedures included, among others, involving an actuarial specialist to assess the method and assumptions used by the Company .

 Delta Air Lines, Inc., a Delaware corporation, provides scheduled air transportation for passengers and cargo throughout the United States and around the world . We are not the primary beneficiary of, nor do we have a controlling financial interest in, any variable interest entity . We have marketing alliances with other airlines to enhance our access to domestic and international markets .
 Recent Accounting Standards Board issued Accounting Standards Update ("ASU") No. 2023-07, "Segment Reporting (Topic 280): Improvements to Reportable Segment Disclosures." This standard requires disclosure of significant segment expenses and other segment items by reportable segment . We adopted this standard effective January 1, 2024. We are assessing the impact of this ASU and, upon adoption, may be required to include certain addiations .
 The company's significant accounting policies are disclosed below or included within the topic-specific notes included herein .  Costs include raw material consumed plus direct manufacturing costs (such as labor, utilities and supplies) as incurred and an applicable portion of manufacturing overhead . Inventories of expendable parts related to flight equipment are carried at moving average cost and charged to aircraft maintenance materials and outside repairs as consumed . An allowance for obsolescence is provided over the remaining useful life of the related fleet .
 Our long-lived lived assets include property and equipment, net and operating lease right-of-use assets . Our tangible assets consist primarily of flight equipment, which is mobile across geographic markets . Our derivative contracts are recognized at fair value on our balance sheets . We may enter into derivative contracts and adjust our derivative portfolio as market conditions change .
 Depreciation and amortization expense related to our property and equipment was $2.5-billion, $.3.3 billion and $.1 billion for the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022 . Residual values for owned aircraft, engines, spare parts and simulators are generally  referred value of cost .
 The airline has a purchasing card with American Express for the purpose of buying jet fuel and crude oil . The card carried a maximum credit limit of $1.1 billion as of December 31, 2024 and must be paid monthly . We record maintenance costs related to our mainline and regional fleets in aircraft maintenance materials and outside repairs .
 Maintenance costs are expensed as incurred . Power-by-the-hour contracts transfer certain risk to third-party service providers . Advertising costs in passenger commissions and other selling expenses in the year the advertising first takes place . We defer sales of passenger tickets to be flown by us or that we sell on behalf of other airlines in air traffic liability .
 The air traffic liability primarily includes sales of passenger tickets with scheduled departure dates in the future and travel credits, which can be applied as payment toward the cost of a ticket . Delta Air Lines, Inc. recognized approximately $6.5.5-billion, $7.4-billion and $4.2-billion in passenger revenue during the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022 .
 Customers can earn miles by flying on Delta, Delta Connection carriers and other airlines that participate in the program . Miles are redeemable by customers for air travel on Delta and other participating airlines, access to Delta Sky Club and other program awards . The program includes two types of transactions that are considered revenue arrangements with multiple performance obligations . See below for discussion of our loyalty program accounting policies .
 Customers earn miles based on their spending with participating companies, such as credit card, ridesharing, retail, car rental and hotel companies . We record the air transportation portion of the passenger ticket sales in air traffic liability and recognize passenger revenue when we provide transportation . We recognize mileage breakage proportionally during the period in which the remaining miles are actually redeemed .
 During the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022, total cash sales from marketing agreements related to our loyalty program were $7.4.4-billion, $6.9.9-billion and $5.7billion, respectively, which are allocated to travel and other performance obligations, as discussed below .
 The amount of miles awarded is based on the amount of service provided by the airline . Revenue allocated to the program is recognized as part of the program's other revenue . The amount is not included in the program’s other revenue, which is recorded as ‘non-discretionary’ and ‘not related’ to the service provided .
 The loyalty program deferred revenue classified as a current liability represents our estimate of revenue expected to be recognized in the next twelve months based on projected redemptions . This represents refinery sales to third parties . The majority of new miles have historically been redeemed within  two years of being earned . This also includes the redemption of miles for non-travel awards .
 The airline segment's operating revenue is recognized in a specific geographic region based on the origin, flight path and destination of each flight segment . A significant portion of the refinery segment's revenues typically consists of fuel sales to support the airline, which is eliminated in the Consolidated Financial Statements . The refinery segment is included in the domestic region of the airline segment .
 Delta Air Lines, Inc. | 2024 Form 10-K66.66: "Fair value" is defined as an exit price, representing the amount that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants . We record a liability when the amounts are collected and reduce the liability when payments are made to the applicable government agency or operating carrier (i.e., for codeshare-related fees).
 The fair value of these cash equivalents is based on a market approach using prices generated by market transactions involving identical or comparable assets . Cash equivalents generally consist of money market funds, time deposits, commercial paper and negotiable certificates of deposit, which primarily relate to proceeds from debt issued to finance the construction costs for our new terminal facilities at New York's LaGuardia Airport as well as certain self-insurance obligations .
 Long-term investments measured at fair value primarily consist of equity investments . Valuation techniques that incorporate observable inputs such as quoted market prices, interest rates, benchmark curves, credit ratings of the security and other observable information . Our equity investments in private companies are classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy as their equity is not traded on a public exchange . Fair value measurement using unobservable inputs is inherently uncertain .
 Monroe's fuel hedge portfolio may consist of a combination of options, swaps or futures . Risk from changing fuel prices are related to Monroe’s inventory . Equity investments reinforce our commitment to these relationships and generally enhance our ability to offer input to the investee on strategic issues and direction . We record our share of our equity method investees' financial results .
 At December 31, 2024, Delta Air Lines, Inc. held 14.8% of outstanding shares (including common and preferred), and  14.9% of the common shares, of Hanjin KAL. We elected to account for our investment under the fair value option. in our income statement as described in the table below .
 Wheels Up is not consolidated in our financial statements . We recorded the immaterial fair value of the guarantee in other noncurrent liabilities on our balance sheet . As of December 31, 2024, we have approximately $395,480,000 of unrecognized equity method losses related to our  49% interest in Virgin Atlantic .
 In 2024, we sold in multiple transactions our equity ownership in Clear Secure, Inc. ("CLEAR") This sale is recorded in gain/(loss) on investments, net on our income statement and cash proceeds are recorded in other, net investing activities on our cash flows statement . We apply a fair value-based impairment test to the carrying value of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets on an annual basis .
 We value goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets primarily using market and income approach valuation techniques . We recognize an impairment charge if the asset's carrying value exceeds its estimated fair value . Factors which could cause impairment include (1) negative trends in our market capitalization, (2) reduced profitability resulting from lower passenger mile yields or higher input costs .
 Definite-lived intangible assets consist of marketing and maintenance service agreements and are amortized on a straight-line basis or under the undiscounted cash flows method over the estimated economic life of the respective agreements . Costs incurred to renew or extend the term of an intangible asset are expensed as incurred as incurred .
 This primarily relates to our slots at New York-LaGuardia and Washington-Reagan National airports . Amortization expense was $9.9 million for the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022 . We estimate that we will incur approximately $7.7 million of amortization expenses annually from 2025 through 2029 .
 The applicable interest rates will begin to adjust for each loan in April 2025, January 2026 and April 2026 . Delta Air Lines, Inc. extinguished an aggregate principal amount of $844 million related to a portion of the SkyMiles Term Loan and various secured and unsecured notes . Delta received a second investment grade credit rating in September 2024 .
 Market risk associated with our fixed- and variable-rate debt relates to the potential reduction in fair value and negative impact to future earnings, respectively, from an increase in interest rates . The fair value of debt, shown below, is principally based on reported market values, recently completed market transactions and estimates based on interest rates, maturities and credit risk . Debt is primarily classified as Level 1 or Level 2 within the fair value hierarchy .
 Certain of our debt agreements limit our ability to (1) incur liens under certain circumstances, (2) dispose of collateral and (3) engage in mergers and consolidations or transfer all or substantially all of our assets . The notes secured by our non-Pacific slots, gates and routes are also subject to a collateral coverage ratio .
 We use the rate implicit in the lease to discount lease payments to present value, when readily determinable . Some of our aircraft lease agreements include provisions for residual value guarantees . These guarantees represent an immaterial portion of our lease liability . We allocated consideration in each capacity purchase agreement to the lease and nonlease components based on their relative standalone fair values .
 Leases reflect our use of airport terminals, office space, cargo warehouses and maintenance facilities . We generally lease space from government agencies that control the use of the airport . Leases are primarily for space at approximately 300 airports around the world that we serve . At the majority of U.S. airports, the lease rates depend on airport operating costs or use of facilities .
 The amounts of these lease and nonlease components are not significant . The interest portion of straight-line rent expense related to fleet operating leases was $165 million and $189 million during the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively . Delta Air Lines, Inc.  the lease asset and lease liability balances on our balance sheets .
 The table below presents certain information related to the lease costs for finance and operating leases . Expenses are primarily classified within aircraft rent, landing fees and other rents and regional carrier expense on our income statement. The lease costs are based on aircraft rent and landing fees . The lease cost is $4,224-$3,620 per year. The cost of the operating leases is $1,225-$1,230.
 In 2023, we substantially completed all construction for the LAX upgrade and modernization project that consolidates Terminals 2 and 3, as well as connects these terminals to the Tom Bradley International Terminal . The project cost approximately $2.5 billion . A substantial majority of the project costs were funded through the Regional Airports Improvement Corporation ("RAIC"), a California public benefit corporation, using a revolving credit facility provided by a group of lenders .
 In 2024, Delta substantially completed all construction for the replacement of Terminals C and D of the New York-LaGuardia Airport with a new state-of-the-art terminal facility . The project cost approximately $4.2.2 billion and was funded through debt issuance, existing cash and a Port Authority contribution . Costs incurred by Delta are accounted for as leasehold improvements recorded in property and equipment, net .
 We sponsor defined benefit pension plans for eligible employees and retirees . These plans are generally closed to new entrants and frozen for future benefit accruals . Under current legislation, any required funding would be amortized over a rolling 15-year period and calculated using a discount rate of no less than 4.75% through 2030 .
 Delta Air Lines, Inc. | 2024 Form 10-K: We have generally eliminated company-paid post age  healthcare coverage . We provide certain other welfare benefits to eligible former or inactive employees after employment but before retirement, primarily as part of the disability and survivorship plans . Substantially all employees are eligible for benefits under these plans in the event of death or disability .
 Service cost shown above relates to the market based cash balance plan . There is no service cost associated with traditional frozen defined benefit plans . At the end of each year presented, our accumulated benefit obligations for our pension plans are equal to the benefit obligations shown above . During 2024, net actuarial gains decreased our benefit obligation primarily due to the increase in discount rates . Net actuarial losses increased benefit obligation . Amounts are generally amortized from AOCI over the expected future lifetime of plan participants .
 Delta Air Lines, Inc. is unfunded at December 31, 2024 . Service cost shown above relates to the market based cash balance plan . There is no service cost associated with traditional frozen defined benefit plans . Service costs are recorded in salaries and related costs in the income statement, while all other components are recorded within miscellaneous, net under non-operating expense .
 The investment strategy for our defined benefit pension plan assets is to earn a long-term return that meets or exceeds our annualized return target . This is achieved by investing in a globally diversified mix of public and private equity, fixed income, real assets, hedge funds and other assets and instruments . Changes in life expectancy may significantly impact our benefit obligations and future net periodic cost/(benefit)
 Delta Air Lines, Inc. easuring pension and other postretirement and postemployment benefit obligations . Actual benefit payments may vary significantly from these estimates . The following table summarizes the benefit payments that are expected to be paid in the years ending December 31: Expected future benefit payments are based on the same assumptions used to measure the related benefit obligations.
 Diversifying assets include hedge funds implementing long-short, market neutral and relative value strategies that invest primarily in publicly-traded equity, fixed income, foreign currency and commodity securities . These investments are presented net of the related benefit obligation in either noncurrent assets or pension, postretirement and related benefits on the balance sheets depending on the funded status of each plan .
 Investments include corporate bonds, government bonds, collateralized mortgage obligations and other asset-backed securities . Prices are based on pricing models, quoted prices of securities with similar characteristics or broker quotes . Common stock is valued at the closing price reported on the active market on which the individual securities are traded . Cash Equivalents include investments in short-term obligations that are a part of institutional money market mutual funds .
 The Delta common stock investment is managed by an independent fiduciary . These investments include commodities such as precious metals and precious metals-related instruments . Some investments are valued at the closing price reported on the active market on which the individual instruments are traded . Others are priced based on pricing models, quoted prices of securities with similar characteristics or broker quotes .
 Unfunded commitments were $1.3.3 billion for commingled funds, private equity and private equity-related instruments, $287.287 million for fixed income and fixed income-related . instruments . Funds with monthly or more frequent redemptions are generally not eligible for redemption . Investments are made through shares of limited partnerships or similar structures for which a liquid secondary market does not exist .
 These investments include real estate, energy, timberland, agriculture and infrastructure . Real assets are typically valued quarterly by the fund managers using valuation models where one or more of the significant inputs into the model cannot be observed and which require the development of assumptions . The valuation of real assets requires significant judgment due to the absence of quoted market prices .
 The timing of these commitments is based on our contractual agreements with the aircraft manufacturers and remains uncertain due to supply chain, manufacturing and regulatory constraints . Delta Air Lines, Inc. recorded profit sharing expense of $1.4 billion under the program . The timing remains uncertain . The airline entered into a purchase agreement with Airbus for  20 A350-1000 aircraft, with an option to purchase an additional 20 widebody aircraft .
 The following table shows our minimum obligations at December 31, 2024 under our existing capacity purchase agreements with third-party regional carriers . We are entitled to all ticket, cargo, mail, in-flight and ancillary revenues associated with the flights under these capacity purchase arrangements . The obligations set forth in the table contemplate minimum levels of flying by the regional carriers under the respective agreements .
 Our VISA/MasterCard and American Express credit card processing agreements provide that no cash reserve is required, and no withholding of payment related to receivables collected will occur . We did not have a Reserve or an amount withheld as of December 31, 2024 or 2023 . We are the lessee under many commercial real estate leases .
 Some of our aircraft and other financing transactions include provisions that require us to make payments to preserve an expected economic return to lenders if that return is diminished due to specified changes in law or regulations . Some of these financing transactions also bear the risk of changes in tax laws that would subject payments to non-U.S. lenders to withholding taxes . As of December 31, 2024, we had approximately  103,000 employees .
 Approximately 20% of airline employees are represented by unions . Delta Pilots are in discussions with representatives of PAFCA regarding terms of the collective bargaining agreement that became amendable on November 1, 2024 . Delta Flight Superintendents (Dispatchers) and Delta Flight Attendants are also represented by unionized workers .
 The following table presents the principal reasons for the difference between the effective tax rate and the U.S. federal statutory income tax rate . Deferred tax assets and liabilities are net by jurisdiction and are recorded as noncurrent on the balance sheets . Delta Air Lines, Inc. | 2024 Form 10-K: 2024 FK: "We account for deferred income taxes under the asset and liability method"
 As of December 31, 2024, Delta Air Lines, Inc. had approximately $2.7 billion of U.S. federa assets . Valuation allowance is recorded to reduce deferred tax assets when necessary . At December 31, 2024 our net deferred tax liability balance was $.1 billion, including a $.951 million valuation allowance .
 The amount of, and changes to, our uncertain tax positions were not material in any of the years presented . We are currently under audit by the IRS for the 2024 and 2023 tax years . We have not recorded a valuation allowance on our deferred tax assets other than net realized and unrealized capital losses and certain state net operating losses that have short expiration periods .
 During 2020 and 2021, in connection with the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act of 2020 (the "CARES Act") payroll support program ("PSP") and extensions, we issued warrants to the U.S. Department of the Treasury to acquire more than a million shares of Delta common stock, which have subsequently been sold to a third party . The number of warrants outstanding slightly increased and the exercise price of the warrants slightly decreased since December 31, 2023 due to adjustments resulting from dividend payments .
 As of December 31, 2024, there were  rewarded 4.3.3 million unvested restricted stock awards . Restricted stock is common stock that may not be sold or otherwise transferred for a period of time and is subject to forfeiture in certain circumstances . Unrecognized costs related to shares and stock options totaled $427.2 million .
 As of December 31, 2024, there were 4.8 million outstanding exercisable stock option awards with a weighted average exercise price of $50.41 . Stock options granted with an exercise price equal to the closing price of Delta common stock on the grant date and generally have a    ten-year term .
 Performance Restricted Stock Units (PRSU) are long-term incentive opportunities that provide executive officers with the right to receive shares of Delta stock based on our achievement of certain performance conditions . PRSUs were first granted to executive officers in 2022 . Potential performance award payments range from 0%-%-200% of a target level and are contingent upon our achieving certain financial and operational goals over a three-year performance period .
 The airline segment is managed as a single business unit that provides scheduled air transportation for passengers . The refinery segment provides services to the airline segment . Delta Air Lines, Inc. | 2024 Form 10-K: $2.2 billion from AOCI, $3.1 billion from a non-operating expense, $4,979 billion from pension and other benefits liabilities .
 The company operates the refinery and related assets located near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, as part of its strategy to mitigate the cost of the price of jet fuel . The gross fair value of the products exchanged under these agreements during the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022 was $1.5 billion, $2.4 billion, respectively .
 Monroe is able to blend only a small amount of renewable fuels into the gasoline and on-road diesel fuel it produces . Renewable fuel compliance costs are accrued in accounts payable each period . Purchased RINs are carried at the lower of cost and net realizable value and are recorded in prepaid expenses and other .
 The nature of other segment items for the airline segment are shown on the income statement and for the refinery segment include salaries and related costs . See table below for detail of the intersegment operating revenue amounts . The airline segment is included within aircraft fuel and related taxes and ancillary businesses and refinery in our income statement .
 Refinery segment operating results are included within aircraft fuel and related taxes in our income statement . We determine market price for jet fuel from the refinery by reference to the market index for the primary delivery location, which is New York Harbor . We calculate basic earnings per share by dividing net income by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding, excluding restricted shares .
 Delta Air Lines, Inc. | 2024 Form 10-K: We did not make any changes in our internal control over financial reporting that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely, to materially affect, our internal controls . Management concluded that the controls and procedures were effective as of December 31, 2024 to ensure that material information was accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer .
 Internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements . Projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies may deteriorate . Ernst & Young LLP audited Delta Air Lines, Inc. for the year ended December 31, 2024 .
 In our opinion, Delta Air Lines, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024, based on the COSO criteria . We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws .
 Internal Control Over Financial Reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding reliability of financial reporting . Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company . We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion .
